meanings.def: having skin that is very light in colour; having skin that has less colour than usual because of illness, a strong emotion, etc.
examples: a pale complexion
She was tall with a slender figure and pale skin.
pale with fear/shock
to go/turn/grow pale
You look pale. Are you OK?
Her face had grown deathly pale.
The ordeal left her looking pale and drawn.
She was tall, dark and pale, and very beautiful.
Ruth went pale as the news sank in.
He turned deathly pale.
His face went pale with anger.

meanings.def: light in colour; containing a lot of white
examples: pale blue eyes
a paler shade of green
a pale sky
The flowers were pale and wilted.
the cold pale light of dawn
She (= her face) paled visibly at the sight of the police car.
The blue of the sky paled to a light grey.

meanings.def: to seem less important when compared with something else
examples: Last year's riots pale in comparison with this latest outburst of violence.
Our problems pale into insignificance when compared to theirs.

idioms.idiom: pale beside/next to something | pale in/by comparison (with/to something) | pale into insignificance
idioms.def: to seem less important when compared with something else
examples: Last year's riots pale in comparison with this latest outburst of violence.
Our problems pale into insignificance when compared to theirs.

meanings.def: considered by most people to be unacceptable or unreasonable
examples: His remarks were clearly beyond the pale.
She has put herself beyond the pale (= behaved in a way that is not acceptable).
